Mattei et al. studied early brain development under simulated µG using human embryonic stem cell-derived neural organoids . The impact of a lack of gravitational force on biological systems can be observed soon after the exposure begins . After a 24 h incubation in a sim-µG, a human seminoma cell line exhibited markers of oxidative stress .

The culture medium that fed cells during 3 distinct time points (during the space flight, during the 3 days exposure on the ISS, and following the 3 day exposure on Earth) were recovered and saved frozen at −80 °C . Random forest analysis (RFA) identified 221 biochemicals in blank, ground control, and SPC-flown NSCs .
The BAA catabolism is a formative form of the BAA formative stage of the development of a space shuttle embryo .

Table depicting fold change ratio of the 3 BCAAs, leucine, isoleucine and valine, and their metabolites after 3 days in space (SPC) or ground control (GC) Values in red rectangles represent increased levels of the metabolites in space compared to ground control .  The levels of creatine, creatinine and urea are reduced in NSC-SPC compared to NSCs-GC . However, there is a significant increase in the levels of these metabolites after 39 days in space . Polyamine metabolism revealed a significant . increase in spermidine, while its precursor putrescine and its metabolites acetylated for degradation .

The effect of microgravity on the human body has been increasingly studied over the past several decades . Understanding the gravitational biology of specific cells and organs is essential for successful travel and long-term survival in space .
